titleStmt.title: M52. Anon. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 19p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M52. Anon. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 19p. Paginated [1]-19, wanting p. 5, 14 (two p. 15).

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: Anon.

"For many centuries after Britain became an island" the
orian says " "the untamed forest was king." Its moist (mosit) and
mossy (mssy) floor was hidden from heavens eye by a close drawn
curtain of innumerable treetops. " On the matted bough
innumerable birds sang (snag); but their song was only heard by a
few skin clad hunters in the clearings (claetings). Did the desire
to sing come to one of those barbarians savages because he heard (geard) the
birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a
moment? Anyhow, the tree was felled; some sort of hut
was made from its branches; and the clearing became larger;
the birds fewer (f er); and the human voice sang instead. The first
songs are out of door songs; spring songs; summer songs;
winter songs.

Bytuene Mersh and Averil
When spray biginneth to springe,
The lutel foul hath hire wyl
on hyre lud to synge.

Sumer is icumen in,
Lhude sing cuccu

By a bank as I lay
Musing myself alone, hey ho!
A birdes voice
Did me rejoice,
Singing before the day;
And me thought in her lay
She said winter was past, hey ho!

They were out of door songs, because there was no
comfort indoors, little light, and no books. The eye
therefore was more active in in ourselves. The eye is the
young sense; the sense that is attached to the body.
Now and then, by choosing (chooisng) a view carefully to shut out
a chimney or a bungalow, we can still see a fragment of

of what they saw-- a flat fen, reed whispering, water
logged; or a down still covered with turf only.
On the down is the green scar still, to mark the
road along which the travellers came, past the circle where
they were buried; past the stone that marks the meeting place
or the burial place.

xxxxxxx sings because love and spring make him
vocal or the horror of winter dark But, who listens? Somebody
heard that particular song, or it would not have been written
down. The singer then had his audience (audeince); but the audience was
so little interested in his name that he never thought to
give it.

It was the printed book with the authors name attached that
was the death of . After thatThe audience was separated from
the singer. After that (1478) the sing was attached to
the singer. Anon gives place to James or Thomas; he lives in
in a house; and he has books.

The heart of this vast proliferation of printed
pages is the song. The song has the same power over the
reader in the 20th century as over the hearer in the
11th. To enjoy singing, to enjoy hearing (h aring) the song,
must be the deepest rooted and tough of human instincts.
It is an instinct of self-preservation, for only when we
put two and two together to we overcome dissolution. Two
lines, two words, two bricks (bri cks) make way against oblivion.
Making whatever it is gives us life; and the passion
with which we seek for these creations, and attempt to
make them, is of a piece with the instinct that
sets us preserving our bodies from wet, or cold.
But with the printing press came into existence
forces that cover over the original song--books
themselves and the readers of books. Could we at this
this moment X ray the singers mind we shound find
a nimbus surrounding the song; a stream (st eam) of
influences to which so many ugly abstract (abstarct) names have been
given-- influences of society; of education; of
class; material; economic of economic (econmic) stress. So many are they and so
obscure that we may call them nonsense names--
say , and . Nin Crot and Pully are always
at their task. More (?ore) and more [complex]

at their work--tugging, obscuring, distracting. invisible (invisble)some only visible to the writer; others only visible in [rear?]
to the sufferer himself often. More and more complex
they become as time passes. The song is only to be discovered
ixmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx instaneously; in a flash
of recognition; some say they feel it when their beards
bristle (brsitle); others that a thrill runs down the nerves of the
thigh. But the song is there still...
Waves...

That babbling child_like- story (stroy) teller, thatthe gossip at
the farm door, that innocent eyed, very naked, lustful ( u tful),
religious singer, that great axmxmxx & new & aged great artist, Anon, died then (thn)
in in 1476&. With him (hi) died something in the audience-- the
They no longer (nollonger) [illeg.] filled in the pauses (payses), and joined in the chorus
To follow (follw) his fortunes (firtunes) further (futhrer), we must turn to an outsider.
one of those commentators who tell us so much about the
invisible (invisib) influences; about , and .. His name was

had sung his song at the back door in a jargon that was
as uncouth and fxmxmxnxmxmxmxmxmus to
as to ourselves; and more barbarous

Icham for wowing al forwake,
Wery no water in wore
An hendy hap ichable yghent;
Ichot from heven it is me sent

the words were as difficult for him to spell out as for us;
and more for him painful; they were [illeg.] reminders of a savagery of low birth (b rth)
xmxmxmxmxmxmxx tokens of base birth, of a close savage past.
In the background, mxmxmxmxxx of mind stood
the Greeks and the romans; ;
; , . Those were the ancients (anicenits) who
occupied the same place in Harrisons mind that the Elizabethans (Elizabetha)
occupy in our minds. The readers of his time read the
classics, Those were the valuable books that
were chained to the shelves (sleves) in college libraries. The learned (leanred)
read them; and the nobles too. "...our ancient ladies of the
court" were to be found reading the holy scriptures (scrpitures) as
they did their needlework (needlwork); and histories;

The great Elizabethan house is still in existence (exist nce),
sxpxmx standing in its green island of [herb?] grass, separated
often from the high road only by a sxmxmxx dip in the
ground and a low red an old wall. It can be seen lying there, out of
proportion (proprtion) somehow, Either it is too big, or the village
with its eighteenth (eignteen) century (ce tury) and twentieth (tw ntieth) century shops and
villas is too small. With ( ith) its conglomeration (congomeration) of roofs
and chimneys, garden and chapels, it dwarfs its neighbours (n ghbours).
the great Elizabethan (Elizabethna) house dwarfs (dwrafs) its (neig bours)
Inside all is kept as if the were expected. [illeg.]
The rooms are still (sti ll) the rooms the lords and ladies (l ies)
lived in. The upright Elizabethan (Elizabethna) chairs stand round the wall.
Their fringes and their tapestry is not much faded.
The great carved tables are polished nad lustrous.
The carved [great?] chests and cupboards look brand new.
Even the toys and knick-knacks (kicknacks) have survived intact :/ inlaid
boxes; Here are the inlaid work boxes, and the that the Queen [needled?] (nahdle)
as she sat upright on the faded pink day couch. And there,
is the swollen big bellied (bel ied) lute or theorbo,
on which she played, still resonant. The floor
is strewn with rugs; the windows curtained with
silver thread (silv r thraed) brocades; and here are the cut glass Venice
chandeliers [illeg.] which lighted this byegone company.

p.sup:
& the
varnished
pear-shaped
lute
upon which
the Queen
once
played.

div.p:
But where are the Elizabethans people? They were more ephemeral (ehmepral)
than their possessions. Human Life has receded (recded) from this (fromthis)
convoluted iridescent shell; with its fringes and its laces,
its elaborate (elborate) carved legs, its loops (lops) and knots,
festoons and draperies upon which the spring sun of 1940
still shines so strong bright. There is a gulf between them and

ourselves. The chairs and tables are there; but the
, all are untenanted.
Only the furniture remains-- the lacquered, the
highly painted, the ornate, the convoluted (conv luted); the chairs and
tables that must have been so so hard to sit upon;
If they were like their furniture, they were
at once ceremonious; and crude; fantastic yet sharp,
pointed, uncushioned;

The writer who hesitated conscious of his plebian (pelebian)
birth (bith) on the threshold of the great roo, , he was still unspecialised (unspeciali)
undifferentiated. His eye was stimulated ; by the crimsons and
the golds and the greens of the clothing (lothing); by the angles and
patterns on the ceilings (ceilinsg); His ear too was stimulated and
pricked (peicked) by [words?]. Books were read (rea) aloud; each word was given sharpness
and substance (subatnce) by the speaking voice. And then when the lord
or lady took his lute and sang, lilt, rhythm (rhytm), melody was added (addd)
to the substance and sharpness of the words. Words bubbled
in his mind, old words, English words, French ( rech) words, Latin (Ladtin)
words. They were molten (motlen), capable of taking any shape, of
reflecting any colours (nay coloure), of following (folliwng) the ones, of taking the
rhythm (rhymn) of the lute (l te). No grammar bound them tightly; nor did
one society inflict its canons of good taste.
Whether he was (ws) to write or to sing or to paint was an open
question (uetion). The arts were closely interwoven. For a moment
there is a pause on the threshold of the great Elizabethan ( l zabethan)
house, when the artist sees before (begore) [illeg.] him three different paths.
Shall he sing, or paint, or make poems? And then there
rose up from the courtyard (couryard) the crude [voices?] tones of the mummers.
It was the stagethat settled it. Had there been no stage,

no actors, might have been (hev eben) .
, and our first great musician.

The writer then came to birth with difficulty in England--
the writer who is distinct from the minstrel, whose words
are printed. For when familiar letters (lettees) are written in
Biblical prose there must be axmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm
a barrier between what is sayable and what unsayable.
a limit thus to what he can put into words writing.

He is in being , at the beginning of the sixteenth century;
for the printing (priting) press has given him a name; but he is still
unspecialised, undifferentiated. The artist --the person
who stands outside (otside) amxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx, by some impulse
desiring to observe to state rather than to take part -- is not wholly writer,
wholly musician, or wholly painter. It seems possible
that the great English art may not be the art of words.
His eye like a painters, is alive to the colour (clour) of
clothing, of country, of beats and birds; his ear, like
a musicians, is stimulated by the sound of words spoken aloud
His book What he wrote was read outaloud in company. "I spent most of my time"
wrote in playing Glocko at Glecko,
and hearing read .. used
to read to me on and Moll Neville in the
(1617-1619) Every word had its sharpness (sharpnes) weight
its weight & edge given to it by the speaking voice. And then the
lute and the virginals gave lilt, rhythm melody to the
written words. When the fire of London was burning and the citizens loading their goods into boats (intob)
noted that "Hardly one lighter or boat (baot) in three
that had the goods of of a house in it, but there was a
pair of virginals in it." The writers mind was full
of undifferentiated (undiffrentiated) words; old words, new words; French and

Latin. No grammar bound them tightly together. They were
elastic; they could be danced to and sung (su) to. But in
spite of that (psp te of nthat), they could not follow (follw) the pace of the
private voice; the voice that talks intimately, briefly
easily colloquially in doors.

then--- a little man with short hair,
a small band, and cuffs--- standing on the threshold
of the great room at was separate from the sing
er; and separate from the chronicler (chornicler); and
separate, in that he saw the scene with detachment from , the artists
point of view, from his audience. But the book which had given (givn)
his words (hisword) aseparate existence, had brought into being a
little group of readers. And that public began at once at once to
exert its pressure. What is the book that will please
? What is the theme that will recommend
itself to the ? What must he praise (priase)? What must he reject
What (W at) will so work upon the audience that they will
procure for the poet a place, or a pension?
TheseFrom this time onward there are to be the always the
influences always tugging and distorting (distrting) and
thwarting; as also they encourage, stimulate, draw out, help into
life the writers instinct. Some are visible only to the
writer himself; others only to the reader in (i ) time to come.
More and more complex they grow, as the book with the
authors name on it goes out into a more and more

more crowded numerous, a more divided audience, to a public which
[emerging from the silence (silce) of the middle ages ] desires
according to its education, its poverty its to it wealth (weath), now history, now
instruction, now poetry itself, and now what will make them
forget the that life is ugly, or drab. As the book
becomes more covered over with these influences, the thing that the writer ser
set out to say becomes increasingly encumbered (encu bered). It is only
to be discovered in a flash of recognition (recgnition); Some say they
feel it--the original, the vital--when their beards bristle.
Others that a thrill (trhill) runs down the nerves of the thigh.
To disengage the song from its encumbrances becomes as time
goes on, a task for the critic-- that specially equipped
official who was scarcely (carcely) in existence (existnce) when emerged
with his from the depths of silence.

[He had chosen his medium: & The great English art
was to be, not music, not painting, but the art of words.]
We call Spenser an artist, more so than the minstrels (misntels) and
the song writers, because he was aware of his medium (medoum).
He was (H ewas) conscious of the possibilities and of the
limitations (limtations) of the English language (lang age). For why, a Gods name,
may not we, as else the Greekes, hav the kingdome of our owne
language (langauge), and measure our accents by the sound ,
reserving the quantity to the verse? He applied himself (himslef)
to the art.

And Like the chronicler (chornicler), the writer in order to use
his medium consciously, must be aware of the past. There must
be a golden age behind him; and the present must be fallen,
degenerate. But, while the modern writer with a long line
behind him, naturally attacks (at ackes) the generation which

which is just gone, --they but are close enough to have
damaged (dmagaed) what he is seeing partly through their eyes--
the writer in Spensers time had no definite foerebear. antagonist
Spensers rdation revolt is against the language (lanaguge) not against not any particular writer, but with
any particular (particualr) master of it. He has a sense of the decay
of language (langauge), its corruption (cor eptuino) since the purity of ,
rather than a desire to destroy some actual predecessor (predecssor).
He recovered the o old words, Chaucers words. Conscious
perhaps of his own diffusity and sweetness, he tried to recover stiffen (stiff)
his words bu the use of Chaucers words, the old words the Old English speech. But together
with this sense of the past, there was present ,what we have ??? in him
the sense of the future. [The sense of the future of the language (langauge)
is almost extinct now] But then the writer was aware
of the tumult of the Something was happening;
With his acute sense of words, he must have been aware,
with agitation (agitaion), with distress of what license (linece) might (ight) befall
this language (langauge); He must have detected in speech, in
ballads (ballds), everywhere (everyhwere), something loosening, [fraying?], fermenting,
and tried to seize; to harden; to fix the language
that was about (abo) to be. before something happened

With that a joyous fellowship issewed
of Minsterls making goodly merriment
With wanton Bardes and Rhymers impudent
That was the voice too that was heard too in the great room.

For when we see the great Elizabethan (Elizabthan) house--
say, or -- we see the stranded relic that has e
emerged (merged) like the ribs of a wreck on the shore from thxmxmxx its surroundings. Could we see it
as it is said that the airman sees a village field wxmxmxxxx
xxx from the air with thexxxx scars of old roads, other villages
and other houses on it. we should see the great house not alone, but
connected with the village. We (W) should see a ring, an oasis
in the midst of vast (va c) wild country; the road (raod) a track only;
and the oasis like a fortress holding out against (agianst) the
uncultivated land; stored against the everlasting siege of
nature. If the enemy were man, there was armour in (i) the church.
If frost or winter there was grain in the great barn.
That is the connection between great house and small,
between master and labourer (la ouere) that is detailed in the
, and makes indeed the staple of the medieval (mediaveal)
letter writing. But there was also that other connection--
the common belief. That bond between the great house and the
small has faded, till it is like one of those perhaps rather
greener rides still to (stillto) be found in England along which,
antiquaries (abntiquaries) say the rode to . So the
scholars tell us of the roads now faded in the mind.
Long before the Christians came (Christains ocame) the tree was a God;
the sun was a God; Earth was God; Death was a God. the
and how this ancient (anceint) worship lies beneath the other; how

With that a joyous fellowship issued
Of misntrels making goodly merriment
With wanton bardes and Rhymers impudent (imâ udent)
--that voice reached Spenser too in the great room.

If the great Elizabethan (Elizabetahn) house, (, Wilton as we see it
now cluttered with villas and bungalows, looks out
of proportion, it is because (beacuse) the connection between the great house
and the small is lost. If we could see it as it was in Spensers
time we should see rxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx tracks, raying out from the
great gate to the across the fields to the cottage (cooatge), to
the farms, even to the hovels. there was the It was connected, if war came
by the need of men. There was armour stored in the church. And
???the perpetual fight with nature made tracks from the house to the
farm. A common fight linked the noble to the labourer (labourrer).
That connection, the physical, between master and man
is painfully and minutely (minitelt) recorded in the medieval letters.
It is the staple of the whole correspondence (correspon nce)--the But there was
also the other the less visible connection--the common belief.
That bond between the great (grear) house and the small has been
grown over, like the track (t ack) under the hill along whch the
pilgrims rode to Canterbury. No one drives there (the e) now. But when
Spenser came to Penshurst that track (rack) led from one house to another;
pilgrims rode to Canterbury. No one drives there (the e) now. But when
Spenser came to Penshurst that track (rack) led from one house to another;
It led to the village green. It led to the tree: to the well.
In the spring they danced round the Maypole; at midsummer they
lit the bon fire on the hill; at harvest the waggons were crowned (crwoned).
At Christmas the mummers acted their dumb show; the boys came (scame)
wassailing. The roads led to the pagan graces, to the stones

where the old pagan English (Ebglish) had offered sacrifice.
The peasants still went that way, by instinct; in summer
in spring; in summer in winter. The old Gods still lay behind the
Christian God. The Pagan gods were served and worshipped under cover of
at the same time the Christian God. The sun was a God; the earth a goddess (goodess).
Even if the old gods were losing (los ng) their names, the
instinct remained when spring came, or in the cold of winter to do
them homage (h mage), to placate them, to win crops, husbands, health,
destruction (detruction) of foes. The desire (dsire) to enact was coupled with the other
desire--to make something useless; something unconnected (unc nnected) with the
daily struggle, to bring out into the day light embodied their own
natural (natiral) love of play. To be dresseddredged (dresded) up, to embody (emboy) the beliefs
that were still so strong; when so much depended on the sun; but
also to embody (emboy) the instinct (insinct) of pleasure; the That sunken road, that
track of ancient belief lay between the master in the great house
and the peasant in the cottage. In the noble as in the peasant (peasnt) murmured (murmure)
a half articulate anonumous voice murmured of old Gods and evils;
The well and the tree were still haunted. As the [scholars?] (s hpalrs) tell (ll) us
both noble and peasant had the same need to embody (meboy) to present (preresent) to see
the instinct personified (personfied). Along the roads from town to town (twon) from
one great house to another (toanother) came the minstrels (mistrels) the rhymers the jugglers
the bear leaders, the makers of ballads (ballds) and actors of old lege
legends. Even the King and Queen must have their minstrel (misnt esl) to
give voice to the hidden instincts. Even though the actor,
partly because his body is his tool partly because the singer (lsinger)
and the dancer are outside the pale of daily workers and see the
pageant (pagenat) irresponsibly often mockingly, the actor was despised (despsied), they

were necessary. Just as one tolerates the person who says what we
are all too proud or too self conscious to say, the minstrel was
despised (despsied) but tolerated (toelerated). Even the churchmen aware that the homage
was paid not their god but the old discarded god, could not suppress
the minstrels (misnters); all (Alll) they could do was to make the irrepressible
instinct (sinsinct) flow into the correct religious channel. If they could they
constrained the jugglers and the bear leaders and the dancers
to put off their leaves, their bells, and striped clothing (clthing)
and robe themselves (them sleves) in the garb proper to the miracle (miravle) play.

This was a great bond between the great house and the
cottage (coottage). For though the (thoug t eh) great speaking French, English (frech nglish), with
Latin and Greek (reek) on their tongues (to gues), might despise the jargon of the
peasant, they shared the memory of what he was doing when he danced,
they knew the old story he acted. Even to the King himself,
it was certain that an evil spirit (sp it) dwelt in the woman in the
hovel. When the were applied to her she confessed
how she had (h d) gone to sea in a sieve with two hundred (hu dred) other witches (witched)
and danced a reel how she had thrown a cat into the (intot he) sea and
raised a storm (stor) that sunk the kings (kin s) ship. heard (haerd) the
rhymers (r ymers) and the mummers (mummenrs). He was at the (he) festival when the

And after her came jolly june arrayed
All in greene leaves, as she a player were.

He had seen the man at the festival, and noted his green leaves
when the had seen the masque at . It was a revival,
already time had given those green leaves their mystery [illeg.]. Already the
other house was being built: had jotted down in his (h) account
book the sums (ums) he had paid for lathes (laths) and nails and timber to build a
play house. He had given so much for painting the theatre. He

distance he sees them pictorally (pictriallly); grouped, like the
figures (figur s) in a fresco,with the flowers growing at their feet,
behind them marble pillars, trees with bright birds, and
the libbard and the lion couchant (couching) or rampant (rampamt). There is no
tension; no direction but always movement, as the metre
flings its curve of sound that, like a wave, breaks always
on the same place (pace). Folded in this incantation (intation) we drowse (drwose)and
sleep yet always start awake. For the T [illeg.] is illuminated.

<Still there is something anonymous about .
He cannot confine emotions within one person.
He must externalise and symbolise.

But Spenser standing on the threshold of the great room
is half in shadow (shdow), half in light. He is still anonymous
in that he cannot confine emotions within one person.
He must symbolise; exteriorise. If a man is jealous, he cannot (canno)
show it save by making a symbol of jealousy. He must
Jealousy (Jealusy) becomes The feelings of men and women must be
symbolised (symblised) and given a body outside their (th ir) own. He ignores
himself (hims lf), the individual. Yet at the same time, forces are at
work that make him conscious of himself, the man who is
separate from the audience (audeince), who is giving the world (wolrd) something
of himself, who is (whois) conscious of the worlds scorn (scron) and neglect
of what he gives. He is aware of his art as was
not, nor , nor . His is no longer a wandering
voice, but the voice of a man practising an art, and
asking for recognition.

Had the poet remained in the great room, proffering (profferig)
his book to the little group of readers, English poetry

might have (hav) rxmxmxmxxx a book read aloud; a recollection;
something read by the leisured listening in the great room
to some one reading aloud. But there was the other
voice the voice at the back door, the voice that
heard himself--- ...of minstrels making goodly
merriment
With wanton bardes and rhymers impudent.

Spenser himself (ims lf) had heard it. He had (H h) been, it is said,
at the pageant at when to amuse the Queen, an
old story was staged. And Spenser (Soenser) noted the player
dressed in green leaves. The nobles it seems,
had a great love of txxxx those rude (r de) voices. Ironically enough (enoug)
the preacher who was for banishing (banihsing) and such
ancient superstitions (supersttions) was himself forging the very weapon
that gave the old minstrels (misntersl) their le a new lease of life
When said in English at the
beginning (beginng) and end of his sermon he was putting ( tting) English into
high places. He was rescuing it from the back door.
He was teaching the nobles how to read (r ad) English; he was
making that alliance between the peasant and the noble
which was necessary (necssary), should all classes meet together
at the at the at the .

When the Queen and the poet together (togteher) saw the old
pageant (paganet) with the players still wearing green leaves (levaes) at
Kenilworth, the builders of the new theatre were ordering
nails, planks, the xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx first theatre (theate)
was being built, at , among the stews, When the flag
flew, the poor and the rich came together, in the open air,

and on that stage, without any scenery, but richly dressed,
the old mummers were to act not Robin Hood, not ,
not play but , , , ,
and .
